reply_context.text: an ant colony can problem solve. the fact that it is a distributed system isn't problematic, despite the fact that the biological substrate isn't organized into a coherent fixed object.

posts.text: I'm not using "signals" to evoke digital logic, I'm using "signals" to evoke information theory. a g-protein on a cellular membrane binding to a molecule on one side of the membrane and changing its configuration to propagate a chemical reaction on the interior of the cell is "transmitting a signal"

reply_context.text: See, you keep bringing it down to signals, but recent research suggests that the electric impulses generated by the body/brain are side effects of cellular activity, not what the cells 'run' on - that's another example of us assuming something based on what's easier to measure

posts.text: It's possible to have a discussion about whether or not an LLM is "doing more than next token prediction" without having to backdoor in notions of consciousness or whatever magic you want to endow biological brains with.

posts.text: And none of this has clarified what it even means for an LLM to not be predicting beyond the next token, despite the fact that we can slap on a decoder to frozen weights and simultaneously extract predictions for full sequences beyond a single token.
